utterances: Thank you all so much for joining us.
Thank you.
Thank you.
(Soundbite of music)
(Singing) Because I've been too strong for too long and I can't be without you , baby…
Next on NEWS & NOTES, two music industry veterans take us behind the scenes just in time for Sunday's Grammy Awards.
And actress Gabrielle Union says uptight is all right in her new film, ""Daddy's Little Girls.
This is NEWS & NOTES.
I'm Ed Gordon.
On today's Roundtable, Dems make a move to involve more voters up front.
And doping in sports, is it just part of the game?
Joining us from our bureau in New York City is Robert George, editorial writer with The New York Post.
Also there, Marcelo Suarez-Orozco - I see he is not there - professor of globalization and education at New York University.
He joins us today from member station WLIU in Southampton, New York.
And Callie Crossley, social and cultural commentator on the television show Beat the Press seen in the Boston area.
She joins us from member station WGBH.

All right, folks, let's talk a little bit about what we are hearing that the Dems have been, quite frankly, talking about for some time, and that is trying to get more color upfront, if you will, more diversity up front in the primary votes.
We're seeing a shakeup of a tradition, putting Nevada and South Carolina into what they call the first wave of presidential contests along with the traditional votes from Iowa and New Hampshire.
Marcelo, when we see this, what we also see, interestingly enough, is some in-fighting within the Democratic Party.
Some don't want to see this move.
Just what Dems need, more in-fighting.
Indeed.
In a way, it follows the demographic shift taking place in our country.
The gravitational focus of our demography is moving very, very rapidly away from the Northeast and from those traditional states into the West, into the Southwest.
If you look at the census data just released last week, Nevada is now one of the fastest growing states in the country.
And the whole country really is moving, demographically speaking, and we will see a new gravitational center that will be much, much more based in the West, in the Southwest.
And that is increasingly diverse population.
It's a population with a growing share of Hispanic voters.
So this will be, in a way, the story of the country moving forward.
Interestingly enough, Callie, one of the complaints from those who ran for the office of president is that often they believed that Iowa and New Hampshire had too much power.

The momentum swing did not allow those that did not do well in that - in those primaries and the straw vote could not often go on to states that they may have been able to garner more support and more votes in.
We're seeing this in some instances, the ability to even out the playing field for those running for office.
Well, that's an interesting question.
I think you're absolutely right.
Those states have had way too much power, and in this day and time - as Marcelo has pointed out - it doesn't reflect a majority of the population.
So it's crazy now in 2006, 2007, 2008 to be thinking about just Iowa, New Hampshire making the determination about who will be the leaders or the possible potential presidential candidates.
What I think distresses me, though, is I think that I'm not certain that adding these two states is going to make a huge difference.
For me, this is like a band-aid on an already broken system, because you're going to end up having narrowed the whole field very early in the game.
It does not allow for anybody to sort of bubble up from grassroots.
It's just really hard if you're a candidate trying to garner some popular support in other ways.
It's like these machines have complete control and the people are left out of it.
Now having said that, it is important to have a Nevada and a South Carolina because those are the two new additions.

But I think what's going to happen is they're going to end up being in the same way kind of powerful in their own way, and I'm not sure we'll still get down to the folks who are bubbling up -who should be bubbling up from the bottom.

Robert George, so important to those on the Democratic National Committee who are pushing this that they are suggesting that there will be sanctions put in place for candidates who campaign in any state that refuses to follow the 2008 calendar of the primaries and caucuses there.
That was approved on Friday.
Now, we should not that all of this is not official, has not gone into place, will not go into place yet.

But, again, for the DNC to suggest that any candidate who campaigns in a state and not abide by the new calendar will be stripped at the party convention of delegates, one in that state, that's pretty harsh.
Yeah.
And I think that - I mean I think that seems to be a little bit of overkill.
I can understand why they want to try and, you know, shake up the map, if you will.
But I'm not so sure, particularly when you call yourself the Democratic Party - making these kind of autocratic moves seems to go against the name of the party itself.

One thing I will say, though, specifically for the - in the context of the Democrats in the way this map plays out, Callie said it was going to, in a sense, prevent different candidates from bubbling up.
Actually, I think this actually creates an interesting dynamic given how Hillary Clinton is still perceived as the frontrunner.
Well, in a sense, yeah.
We can almost say, you know, we are all East Germans now because that was always the issue in the 70s and 80s, that the Soviet bloc countries used all these performance-enhancing drugs.
And now that seems to, you know, just like weapons of mass destruction, everybody wants to have that edge.
And how…
Yeah.
I mean, everybody wants video.
We want video, too.

Well, it's really remarkable what Bernie Sanders has been able to pull off coming from so far behind at the very beginning of this, having only about a third of the money that Hillary Clinton had and now pulling even with her in the polls and pretty much on par with where she is on fundraising.
Here is the thing.
Anyone who doubted that Bernie Sanders' surge was real, these numbers should really dispel that.
We're at a moment now where candidates are not required to disclose their totals.
Those who have impressive totals have chosen to disclose.
And Ben Carson announced today that he raised $20 million in the last quarter.
That seems like a really impressive number.
It is a very big number when you consider that Ben Carson's campaign essentially collapsed midsummer.
There isn't much infrastructure there that he has.
But one thing that I have noticed with Ben Carson - is somebody that I've covered.
I've seen him since about 2010 with the Tea Party.
And every single Tea Party supporter that I've talked to, the name on the tips of their tongue every single time is Ben Carson.
What do you think of Ben Carson?
I really like Ben Carson.
So it's not surprising for people who've seen him and have seen the Tea Party for a while know that Ben Carson is surging here.

Sounds like the passion for outsiders that we've been seeing all summer, whether it's Ben Carson on the Republican side or Bernie Sanders on the Democratic side, is really translating to money, Peter.
Yeah.
The downside for Ben Carson is that his cost of raising money is unusually high.
You know, you have to spend money to get money, and he depends on a lot of very traditional methods - direct mail, buying mailing lists, things like that.
And so his cash on hand is usually very low.
And Hillary Clinton has spent a lot of money as well.
She's only $7 million ahead of Bernie Sanders in cash on hand because it takes a lot of money to create a field organization that can go the long-term, and that's what she's built so far.
That's NPR's Domenico Montanaro and also Peter Overby.
Thanks to both of you.
Thank you.
You're welcome.
Good morning, I'm Steve Inskeep.
Elsewhere today, we report that cutting back fat may not help your health.
People in Juneau, Alaska knew that.
They held the Second Annual Juneau Baconfest this month.
It includes a hog-calling contest, a bacon eating contest and special dishes like bacon caramel brownies.
The star attraction was a bacon bustier worn by a model.
Its creator said the only real problem here was keeping her cats away while she made it.
You're listening to MORNING EDITION.
Talks on Iran's nuclear program are entering a crucial weekend.
The deadline for reaching the broad outlines of a deal is Tuesday.
The U.S.
seeks to prevent Iran from building a nuclear weapon.
The goal for Iran is relief from economic sanctions.
NPR's Peter Kenyon is in Switzerland, where the talks are taking place, and he explains why lifting sanctions is tricky and contentious.
When Iran's leaders talk about sanctions, it's usually to declare them both illegal and ineffective.
And yet getting sanctions lifted as quickly as possible remains Tehran's top priority.
(SOUNDBITE OF PERSIAN NEW YEAR CELEBRATION)
During the recent Persian New Year celebration, Supreme Leader Ayatollah Ali Khamenei told a mosque gathering that a U.S.
proposal to suspend certain sanctions and lift others only after Iran follows through on its nuclear commitments is not to be trusted.
(SOUNDBITE OF SPEECH)
(Through interpreter) This is an American trick.
They say, we make a deal, and then we monitor Iran's behavior and then lift the sanctions.
It is not like that.
The sanctions should be removed immediately after the agreement.
U.S.
and European officials say there's little doubt that a remarkable nexus of sanctions from the U.S., EU and U.N.
Security Council played a big role in bringing Iran to the table.

The issue, now that Iran appears willing to make tangible concessions to prove it's not seeking a nuclear weapon, is how to provide sanctions relief without totally giving up the leverage they provide.
It's clear that if there is to be a final deal, Iran will need some early sanctions relief to quiet hard-line critics back home.
There are plenty of frozen Iranian assets that could be released, but that's not lifting sanctions, which is what Iran's leaders have promised their people.
This may be where the U.N.
sanctions come in.

With all five permanent members of the Security Council at the table with Iran, there's little to stop the council from simply passing a new resolution that either suspends or cancels some of the sanctions.
The U.N.
sanctions aren't that important economically but they may be important to Iran's sense of national pride.
Analyst Jim Walsh with the Security Studies Program at MIT says Tehran was stung by these sanctions, coming as it were, from the entire international community.
Certainly the lifting of U.N.
sanctions would carry a bigger punch.
It would be something tangible - not in effect, but in principle - that the Iranian public could recognize and for which Rouhani and his administration would get credit.
There are pitfalls for both sides.
U.S.
officials worry that once lifted U.N.
sanctions could be hard to replace since Russia or China could veto them.
They're seeking a suspension, preferably with a mechanism to restore sanctions, if Iran doesn't comply with a nuclear deal.
Meanwhile, Iran would want some U.N.
action to ensure that the U.S.
and its allies live up to their end of any bargain.
When it comes to the American sanctions, some were imposed by President Obama, and those he can suspend or left.
Even some congressional sanctions could be waived by the president.
Lifting others, however, would require a congressional vote.
The toughest sanctions are the ones keeping Iran out of the global banking system.
Analyst Jim Walsh says if those were lifted and Iran then violated the agreement, they could probably be reimposed because most countries tend to abide by them to stay in the banking system.
In some ways, the U.S.
always has this in their back pocket.
The European banks and Chinese banks aren't going to want to risk falling out of favor with the international banking system, even if they want to do business with Iran.
Even print reporters like Shelley Murphy of the Boston Globe.
Most of the major veterans groups have made similar statements.
The VFW called ideologues inside the White House, quote, ""a cancer inside this administration."" The dispute laid bare a long-brewing conflict inside the Trump administration.
